title: With Power Restored, Texans Face Storm Aftermath
summary: Clean water and some foods remain hard to come by; some residents receive high utility bills. Millions of Texans starting to recover from deadly winter storms are contending with water-quality issues, food shortages and, for some, skyrocketing utility bills, even as power and higher temperatures had returned.

title: Why Cuomo Should Be Worried About a Federal Probe
summary: His administration appears to have engaged in a coverup to frustrate federal oversight.. The Cuomo administration's alleged misreporting of nursing-home deaths in New York is serious, perhaps meriting federal criminal charges.

title: The Non-Covid Spending Blowout
summary: Most of the $1.9 trillion House bill has little to do with the virus. Here's a breakdown.. The Biden White House is pointing to polls showing that its $1.9 trillion spending bill is popular, and the press corps is cheering. Yet we wonder how much public support there'd be if Americans understood that most of the blowout is a list of longtime Democratic spending priorities flying under the false flag of Covid-19 relief.

title: The Money Boom Is Already Here
summary: Since February 2020, the M2 supply has increased 26%-the largest one-year jump since 1943.. Speculative manias are in the air, as evidenced by the recent price surges for bitcoin, a digital asset with a fundamental value of zero, and GameStop , a declining retailer. Along with the other economic trends-a strong recovery, surging commodity prices and an uptick in inflation-those asset bubbles have a clear cause: the massive expansion of money and credit.

title: 'Stimulus' Does Little for Jobs
summary: Companies won't make permanent investments in new employees based on temporary revenue.. The Biden administration says if Congress passes the proposed $1.9 trillion Covid relief bill, we won't have to "wait for years for the economy to return to full employment," as two members of the Council of Economic Advisers put it in a recent White House blog post.

title: AMLO's Plan to Drop Texas Gas
summary: Gov. Greg Abbott inadvertently gives Mexico protectionist arguments in energy.. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott's decision last week to ban natural-gas exports to Mexico temporarily was shortsighted and counterproductive for his state.

title: The Most Popular Shows You've Never Seen
summary: Even when TV was a 'vast wasteland,' it brought us together.. Newton Minow famously called television a "vast wasteland": "a procession of game shows, formula comedies about totally unbelievable families, blood and thunder, mayhem, violence, sadism, murder, western bad men, western good men, private eyes, gangsters, more violence, and cartoons. And endlessly, commercials. . . . And most of all, boredom."

title: 'Mr. Humble and Dr. Butcher' Review: A Heart in the Right Place
summary: The pioneer of head-transplant surgery believed that the soul resides in the brain and could be rescued from physically compromised bodies.. The "title characters" of Brandy Schillace's admirable biography "Mr. Humble and Dr. Butcher: A Monkey's Head, the Pope's Neuroscientist, and the Quest to Transplant the Soul" were one and the same person: Robert J. White, a distinguished neurosurgeon, an accomplished neuroscientist and a man dedicated to searching for the means to transplant souls by transplanting the human brain. If this makes White sound macabre, Ms. Schillace's account of his life, work and temperament is anything but. She deftly persuades the reader to take White seriously (he wasn't even eccentric) and to ponder profound medical-scientific-philosophical issues. Best of all, the book is fascinating.

title: Travel's Covid-19 Blues Are Likely Here to Stay-'People Will Go Out of Business'
summary: The tourism industry, which hoped for a rebound from the pandemic in 2021, is bracing for a slower recovery. The outlook for a rebound in travel this year has dimmed after the global pandemic ravaged the industry and hurt tourism-dependent economies, with travelers postponing plans amid vaccine delays and border restrictions.

title: Restaurant-Software Provider Toast Prepares for IPO
summary: Toast taps Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase to underwrite a possible listing later this year. Toast Inc. is planning an initial public offering that could value the restaurant-software provider at around $20 billion, people familiar with the matter said.

title: When Covid-19 Hit, Mayo Clinic Had to Rethink Its Technology
summary: One example: The healthcare provider had to make close to 3,000 changes in its electronic health-records system. Mayo Clinic, like many health providers, has been pushed to its limits by the Covid-19 pandemic. Its intensive-care units were often filled to or near capacity in 2020. And while doctors throughout the health system rushed to find ways to care for the wave of sick patients infected by the new virus, many of the medical and support staff were being sent home to work remotely.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Fed, Jobless Claims, Consumer Spending
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell will deliver the central bank's semiannual report on the economy and monetary policy to Congress. U.S. consumer spending highlights this week's economic data.

title: Why Beijing Loves Biden and Paris
summary: The U.S. rejoins a climate pact that gives China a free carbon ride.. The U.S. officially rejoined the Paris climate accord on Friday to much media and European applause. Our guess is that China is the most pleased because it knows the accord will restrict American energy while Beijing gets a decade-long free ride.

title: Trump Is Flawed but Don't Shun His Voters
summary: As William Galston points out, the only purge which is coming to pass, albeit thus far on the state level, is that of those isolated Republicans who voted to convict.. Regarding William A. Galston's "The GOP Won't Purge Trump" (Politics & Ideas, Feb. 17): Now that the gang that couldn't impeach straight blew its chance to cancel any possibility of President Trump pulling a Grover Cleveland act in 2024, the chasm between the old, establishment Republican guard and the Trump-transmogrified GOP base has naturally widened. And as Mr. Galston pertinently points out, the only purge which is coming to pass, albeit thus far on the state level, is that of those isolated Republicans who voted to convict.

title: Macron Fights Terror but Steps on Parents
summary: Emmanuel Macron is forcing through a law that effectively renders home schooling illegal for most parents.. Regarding your editorial "Emmanuel Macron and the Woke" (Feb. 18): While I welcome French President Macron's apparent opposition to "wokeness," far from restoring "classical liberal values," he is forcing through a law that effectively renders home schooling illegal for most parents. Just as the German government in 1938 threatened parents with prison if they did not send their children to school from age 6, France will soon require all children from age 3 to attend school or else. Few truly independent options exist, as even the Catholic schools follow the state curriculum with full state funding.

title: Big Automotive Chip Shortage Is No Surprise
summary: The focus on lean should have been balanced with a pragmatic view on the extreme cost of idled automotive production lines.. "Car Makers Collide With Global Chip Shortage" (Page One, Feb. 13) correctly identifies the auto industry's current supply-chain woes as a self-inflicted wound. From the electronics-manufacturing industry's point of view, automotive is mostly a low-volume, high-mix customer segment, and it requires buffering through component distributors. Instead, the auto makers' extreme focus on cost optimization and lean manufacturing meant eliminating these valuable supply-chain partners. The focus on lean should have been balanced with a pragmatic view on the extreme cost of idled automotive production lines. To shut down production lines for $80,000 vehicles because of a missing $2 microcontroller is catastrophic.

title: A Stock-Trading Dupe Is Born Every Minute
summary: The recent hearing on Robinhood missed the basics of how pump-and-dumps work.. Michael J. Meehan and friends started buying a tech company's shares, but from each other, driving up the price on each trade. Others noticed the rising stock and started buying too, sending shares to more than $100. Then everyone piled in until it hit around $500 at its peak. Sound familiar? GameStop ? AMC? Nope. It was RCA, pumped by the so-called Radio Pool in 1928-29.

title: Israel Dodges Questions on Secret Vaccine-for-Prisoner Deal With Syria
summary: Prime Minister Netanyahu confirms negotiations with Russia but denies Israel supplied its own vaccines in deal to bring back an Israeli woman stuck in Syria. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has sidestepped questions over whether his country agreed to pay Russia to provide coronavirus vaccines to Syria as a part of a prisoner swap between the two Middle Eastern countries.

title: WHO Said What About Wuhan?
summary: International investigators ignore the lab-leak theory but investigate frozen fish.. Chinese policy makers have been floating an implausible theory: The novel coronavirus didn't originate in China but was imported from Europe. That's what a former chief epidemiologist of the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention told an academic conference last fall. One theory is the virus rode into Wuhan on frozen-food packaging.

title: U.S. Report Allows Russian Pipeline Project to Proceed, for Now
summary: Lawmakers criticize Biden administration report that names no new Nord Stream 2 sanctions targets. The State Department in a report to Congress didn't name new companies as targets for sanctions related to an $11 billion pipeline designed to transmit Russian natural gas to Germany, allowing work on the pipeline to continue unabated for now.

title: Employers Want More Diversity. They May Need to Open Offices in New Places.
summary: Research on race in the workplace suggests executives could close racial gaps within their ranks by being more strategic about geographic locations. Among the key takeaways from a new report on race in the workplace is this surprise: To address inequality inside organizations, some companies may need to open offices in new locations.

title: Israel's Speedy Vaccination Campaign Faces Test in Returning to Normal
summary: Officials combine incentives with threats, offering perks while warning that those who don't get the shot will be shut out of everyday activities. TEL AVIV-Israel lifted restrictions on most commerce and public activity, opening malls, markets and museums-and requiring the use of a pass to document vaccination status for some activities.

title: The Least-Relaxing Pandemic De-Stresser: Tiny DIY Doll Houses
summary: Resume Subscription. After nine months of looking for soothing ways to fill time at home, Kimberli Fancher had already re-tiled her garage floor and built a meditation garden in the backyard. By November, she decided to turn her attention to something smaller: a DIY miniature coffee shop kit.

title: Is a Mid-Career M.B.A. Worth It?
summary: Here's how a number of untraditional M.B.A. candidates leveraged the degree to pivot at work. Conventional wisdom says the best time to go to business school is in your 20s, after working a few years, perhaps while you are still single and trying to move up in the corporate world.

title: What's Keeping Black Workers From Moving Up the Corporate Ladder?
summary: Companies have devoted a lot of attention to diversity in hiring and promotions. A new study offers clues as to why the efforts have fallen short-and what can be done to change that.. American corporations have devoted no shortage of resources or rhetoric toward making workplaces more racially diverse. So why aren't there more Blacks in the management ranks of the business world?

title: China Deploys Covid-19 Vaccine to Build Influence, With U.S. on Sidelines
summary: Resume Subscription. ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia-A cavernous new airport cargo terminal in Ethiopia's capital is the center of a vast supply network China is assembling to speed delivery of its coronavirus vaccines-and deepen its influence across the developing world.

title: GameStop Craze Puts Holders of Retail ETF on Wild Ride
summary: State Street's SPDR S&P Retail ETF shares have surged 23% this year. GameStop mania has spilled over into a popular exchange-traded fund, as the WallStreetBets craze reaches beyond shares favored on social media.

title: Lamont Defends Refusal to Boost Tax on Wealthy
summary: Planned investment in education and cities is criticized by a progressive coalition as not bold enough for Covid-19 economy. Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont's centrist budget plan has put him at odds with a coalition of progressive lawmakers, activists and labor unions calling for tax increases to fund a more robust response to the economic crisis.

title: A Former Baseball Umpire Makes a Call to Become a Veterinarian
summary: On a visit to his father's veterinary clinic, Chris Tiller's childhood dreams came back as he saw his young son's interest. On a visit to his father's veterinarian clinic in Waskom, Texas, Chris Tiller watched his own young son helping out and realized it was time for another career switch.

title: Conagra's Post-Covid Strategy
summary: The maker of Slim Jims, Duncan Hines, Hunt's and Healthy Choice believes it can keep its pandemic boost going. Conagra Brands Inc.'s Sean Connolly has been working to broaden the appeal of dozens of old-fashioned grocery mainstays, such as Hunt's, Slim Jim, Duncan Hines and Healthy Choice, since becoming chief executive officer six years ago.

title: Incitement Case Against Trump Would Present Challenges
summary: Legal experts say a prosecution could be an uphill battle. WASHINGTON-As Donald Trumpwas acquitted at his impeachment trial on one charge of inciting the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, some Republicans suggested that the proper forum to consider the legality of his behavior was a U.S. court.

title: Novak Djokovic Is Making an All-Time Tennis Case
summary: An 18th major title has the Serbian star just two trophies away from rivals Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal. Tennis will have to reckon with Novak Djokovic, sooner or later, because he's charging in the rear view. Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal may have come of age as generational rivals, captivating the sport, and harnessing much of its good will, but as the years go on, and bodies weary, it may be Djokovic-the third man in, and a historic talent himself-who stands alone.

title: Houston Businesses Emerge From Storm
summary: Resume Subscription. HOUSTON-As Henry Nguyen reopened his hair salon in southwest Houston, half a dozen neighbors rushed in-not for haircuts, but to wash their hair. They had gone days without running water at home.

title: British Pound Reaches Strongest Level in Nearly Three Years
summary: Rapid vaccinations and a trade deal with the EU have made some investors bullish on sterling. The British pound got slammed in recent years by the twin storms of Brexit fears and a particularly bad Covid-19 crisis. But with a trade deal in pocket and a world-leading vaccine program, investors say the upside forces for the currency are now just as strong.

title: Can Mass Self-Testing for Covid-19 Keep Schools Safe?
summary: Austria is trying a new strategy to reopen classrooms, as scientists say infections can be reduced with the right safety measures. BERLIN-On a continent still struggling with high Covid-19 rates, one small Alpine country is trying something new to reopen its schools: Require that students test themselves twice a week before they can attend class.

title: Novak Djokovic Wins Australian Open, His 18th Grand Slam Title
summary: The 33-year-old Serbian beat Daniil Medvedev in straight sets to win his ninth title in Melbourne. Every winter, Novak Djokovic has to travel some 10,000 miles to find his backyard.

title: Inflation Problems Depend on Where You Look for Them
summary: If the Fed's low interest rates lead to trouble, the reason might be climbing asset prices rather than consumer prices. The Federal Reserve predicates its easy money policies in part on the fact that its favorite measure of inflation has run more than a half percentage point below its goal for several years.

title: Restaurants and Startups Try to Outrun Uber Eats and DoorDash
summary: Big delivery-app fees gnaw at many restaurants; entrepreneurs and eateries pitch workarounds.

title: For Covid-19 Survivors, One Shot May Be Enough, Studies Show
summary: Data may mean a second dose of the vaccine is unnecessary, potentially freeing up limited supply. Covid-19 survivors who have gotten a first dose of Covid-19 vaccine are generating immune responses that might render a second shot unnecessary, potentially freeing up limited vaccine supply for more people, several new research papers suggest.

title: United Flight Lands in Denver Following Engine Failure
summary: Local police say engine debris damaged property in plane's flight path, but report no injuries. A United Airlines Holdings Inc. flight headed toward Honolulu returned to Denver International Airport after its right engine failed shortly after takeoff, the Federal Aviation Administration said Saturday.
